instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR: What is PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR? This is the input that comes from the charger..
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.ISL9239: What is ISL9239? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2016-2018 responsible for charging the battery and creating the power rail PPBUS_G3H.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Won't turn on
threads.message:
Hi, i have a Macbook Pro Retina Touchbar 15" , No water damage, No corrosion visible, board looks pretty well, but not turning on.

On the USB-C measure tool, gets 5v - 0.0 amps for a second, them try to get some more power and up to 0.03 and the USB-C PowerMeter get off and on again on a infinite loop.

I measure this:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 0.0017v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.34v (For a 3-4 secs and them gets down for a sec or less and gets again up)
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL> 5.21v (For a 5-6 Secs and them gets down around 1.2v for a sec or less and gets again 5.21v)

I really don't know where looks first, so many rails and signals are new in this boards and i don't know who must be present first. 

Any help?

Thanks in advance.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Won't turn on
threads.message:
USB-C controllers seem to be OK.
If board tries to start every 5s, means SMC talks with charger, but detects some error and power goes down.
Does it start in SMC bypass mode?
Check for short, or low resistance to ground on all coils; and F7000/01 too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Won't turn on
threads.message: Bootlooping on all of the ports or just one? Could be an issue with one of the CD3215s. Definitely no corrosion near any of them?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Won't turn on
threads.message:
[QUOTE="JohnB8812, post: 45393"]Bootlooping on all of the ports or just one? Could be an issue with one of the CD3215s. Definitely no corrosion near any of them?[/QUOTE]

On all of them, this logicboard seems cool, no corrosion, no water damage. im pretty sure.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Won't turn on
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 45391"]USB-C controllers seem to be OK.
If board tries to start every 5s, means SMC talks with charger, but detects some error and power goes down.
Does it start in SMC bypass mode?
Check for short, or low resistance to ground on all coils; and F7000/01 too.[/QUOTE]

Resistance to ground on these coils its about 10 milliohms (10M?), how i can test bypassing the SMC? like an old macbooks?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Won't turn on
threads.message:
"Resistance to ground on these coils its about 10 milliohms (10M?)"
First, which coils?
I didn't mention any; F7000/01 are fuses from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
Second, M on DMM display means Megohms...

Measure on diode mode, red probe to ground; disconnect any power first.
Start checking on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.

If 5V goes off every 5s, is because the board try to start and some sensor error forces SMC to restart it.
Starting in SMC bypass can confirm/discard that.

BTW, do not quote an entire previous post; is not aesthetic.
Quote only the text you want to refer.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Won't turn on
threads.message: If PPDCIN is only getting to 5 volts, something is pulling it down usually one of the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips. Inject 3.3 volts on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> and see if there is any current consumption. If so, use freeze spray or alcohol or whatever to see if one of the CD3215s is causing it. In my experience, the one that often fails is <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>, but it could be any of them!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Won't turn on
threads.message:
The board gets only 5V as normal in the first moment.
After SMC talks with the charger, voltage should go high, to nominal value.
In your case seems the voltage drops just in that moment.
This makes me suppose SMC talks with charger and ask it for nominal voltage; that is not possible if one <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> is bad.
The issue should be after <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.

"Measure on diode mode, red probe to ground; disconnect any power first.
Start checking on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>."

Second, M on DMM display means Megohms...

Measure on diode mode, red probe to ground; disconnect any power first.
Start checking on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.

If 5V goes off every 5s, is because the board try to start and some sensor error forces SMC to restart it.
Starting in SMC bypass can confirm/discard that.

BTW, do not quote an entire previous post; is not aesthetic.
Quote only the text you want to refer.[/QUOTE]

Ok my mistake, i mean fuses, on these fuses. And, i take a picture for you of my measures on the fuses so you let me know the resistance, i think this is milliohms.

So, i do the SMC Bypass too and stuck on 5.21v - 0.00 A on the meter on all USB-C Ports.

Any other idea? 

Thanks !

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Won't turn on
threads.message:
In the photo you have Megohm value....
Select diode mode for the future.
However, not needed now; as you don't have low value.
Check for any voltage pulse at F7000.
An o-scope will help better, to catch the pulse level.
If get something, check if other coils pulses too.
Any pulse at any <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5</SIGNAL>/4/<SIGNAL>3_L</SIGNAL>, or <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Won't turn on
threads.message:
Ok, here is the measure of all single coils on the board in ohms. If any measure go to ohms scale i will take diode mode in this too. here we go..

L2959: 1.3k on both sides.

L3500: starts in 20k and goes down slowly and when get 15k get more slowly.

L6900: 120k and slowly goes down

LA900: 4.2k on both sides.

L9360: 0.9k on both sides.

L9370: 3.7k on both sides.

L9380: 5.5M and goes down slowly.

L9330: 8.7k on both sides.

LB150: 1.1k on both sides.

LB700: 14k on both sides.

LA350: 32 ohms on both sides and diode mode (Positive probe to ground) has 0.020.

LA650: 3 ohms on both sides and diode mode (Positive probe to ground) has 0.002. Very similar measures on "LA640 - L7330 - L7231 - L7221 - L7211 - L7420 - L7410"

L7030: 1.1M and goes down slowly.

L8000: 65.5 ohms on both sides and diode mode (Positive probe to ground) has 0.029.

L7960: 22.0 ohms on both side and diode mode (Positive probe to ground) has 0.013.

L7900: 140.5 ohms on both side and diode mode (Positive probe to ground) has 0.098.

L7660: 30k on both sides.

L7600: 44k on both sides.

L8410: 190k on both sides.

Have another 4 coils "L6400 - L6401 - L6450 - L6451" But this is for speaker and all of these have values on the kohms scale.

i hope this help you to help me. :)

Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Won't turn on
threads.message: Any help? :(

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Won't turn on
threads.message:
Always start checking in diode mode.
Only switch to ohm mode for very low value; i.e. under 010 diode mode indication.

5V at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> drops every 5 seconds?
Do you have an oscilloscope for checking?
Sometime pulses to the coils, or other signal, are very short and DMM cannot catch them.
Check if <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>, or <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> get a pulse just before 5V drops.
Also monitor <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Won't turn on
threads.message: Inject 3.3 volts in to <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> and monitor for current draw. If there is any draw, see if one fo the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips is pulling the signal low. If there is no current draw, do a diode mode reading around each <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> on <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>, and the 3v3, 1v8, and 1v1 LDO lines.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Won't turn on
threads.message:
Hi again, 

I inject 3.3 volts on pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R6923</RESISTOR> and nothing is getting hot and nothing happening on the power supply. all the time have 0.01 amps and 3.3v stable.  

what do you think? 

No one have an idea?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Won't turn on
threads.message: If no current draw, then this will be hard to figure out what is pulling your DC in line down. One of the CD3215s is likely the issue, but it's hard to figure out which one. Take diode mode readings as previously stated around each chip.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Won't turn on
threads.message:
When F7000/01 removed, do you get steady input 5V?
If not, test removing <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Won't turn on
threads.message: Why do you think the problem is actually one of those <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>? maybe the problem are in another place.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Won't turn on
threads.message:
I asked you to do few test, to locate the problem.
I suppose that SMC tries to start the board and detects something wrong and gets blocked...
<CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> issue (usually) should stuck in steady 5V at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>, or even no voltage passing through their input MOSFETs.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Won't turn on
threads.message:
[QUOTE]When F7000/01 removed, do you get steady input 5V?[/QUOTE]
Nop, never get 5v steady. always gets down. 

[QUOTE]If not, test removing <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> too.[/QUOTE]
If remove <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>, have 5v steady but, no 0,000 amps.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Won't turn on
threads.message:
Seems that your problem is on <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area; maybe the chip itself.
Change <CHIP>ISL9239</CHIP>, no firmware required.
Check first no short through <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>/40.
